story:
My Dad was diagnosed with Stage 4 Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer in June 2020. This is still naturally incredibly raw so we would appreciate your privacy and donations to help support Macmillan UK.

My Dad would like me to add that "1 in 2 people will develop cancer in their lifetime" (Cancer Research UK, 2015). He would very much appreciate it if you could dig deep and give as much as you are able to so we can support Macmillan UK. We understand that people are facing financial hardhsip during these times but any donation or even a share of this page would mean the world to us as a family. All of the funds raised will go directly to Macmillan.

We have decided to create this page and support Macmillan UK as it is a charity very close to us. Macmillan have been able to provide support to our family and many others thanks to donations received and with your help they can continue to support people and their families in many ways. Macmillan produce extensive content and provide information for various different types of cancer, treatment, diet, finances, benefit eligibility, and so much more. The information within these leaflets and books in addition to the support found within their centres or on the telephones are absolutely invaluable to the individual with cancer but also to their friends & family. 

I personally felt less isolated once engaging with Macmillan and I felt more able to beneficially contribute to the wellbeing of not only my Dad but my Mum also. I learned a lot from them and I understood things better. 

If you are experiencing any health issues, please remember that your GP is open and they want to see you. If in doubt, get it checked out.

Set yourself a challenge, give yourself a purpose and take part in an epic day!
Battle Cancer combines playful functional fitness workouts with a teamwork experience like no other. We're not about finding the strongest or fittest, Battle Cancer is a mindset, a community and battling something bigger than us all.

1. Enter as a team of four (all male, all female, or mixed - any combination of gender: 2 men 2 women, 1 man 3 women, 1 woman 3 men. 

2. Fundraise for Macmillan in the lead up to the competition and submit your fundraising total at registration. This will rank you on the leaderboard for your chance to get a leg up on the competition before any fitness takes place!

3. Compete in four 9-minute fitness workouts over the course of the day

4. End on a huge sense of accomplishment

Whether you are participating in the UK, Europe or America - thank you for playing a part in supporting Macmillan.

story:
All of us will know someone close who has battled with cancer, and as knowledge/technology (correct diagnoses etc) advances this will likely increase. 

Me and my family are no exception, in just the last 5 years my nephew had a tough battle with a rare and aggressive brain tumour, and my mother in law had breast cancer.
Thankfully both of these have fought through but continue to be impacted by the struggles and treatments, which will always be a part of them and a constant reminder. 

Unfortunately it is not always possible to pull through and in the same timescale, people we care about have passed away.

Support is so important in helping to deal with not only the direct issue of cancer, but also the wider impact emotionally, physically and with loved ones.

I am only a very small streamer but I am going to try become a "Game Hero", raise a little awareness and maybe a couple of pounds to help support Macmillan, support people effected by cancer.

My efforts will be on my Twitch channel, covered over two 12 hour sessions at https://www.twitch.tv/yorkshirenerdplays
The sessions will be Friday 18th Dec and Saturday 19th Dec 10am until 10pm.
I hope you will join me with a little support.
Anyone who can sponsor me on here, watch the stream, join in with chat or spread the word is massively appreciated.

Raising money for the British Heart Foundation is a natural choice for me.  Through their fantastic research the BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly, every day hundreds of people lose their lives. story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Together with their research partner, the UCL Great Ormond Street Institute of Child Health, the hospital hosts the UK’s only paediatric National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Biomedical Research Centre (BRC). Since its formation in 1852, the hospital has been dedicated to children’s healthcare and to finding new and better ways to treat childhood illnesses.

Great Ormond Street Hospital receives 237,908 outpatient visits and 43,218 inpatient visits every year (figures from 2018/19). Most of the children they care for are referred from other hospitals throughout the UK and overseas. There are 63 different clinical specialties at GOSH; the UK's widest range of specialist health services for children on one site. More than half of their patients are referred to us from outside London and a small proportion come from overseas. GOSH is the largest paediatric centre in the UK for:

  • paediatric intensive care
  • cardiac surgery - they are one of the largest heart transplant centres for children in the world
  • neurosurgery - they carry out about 60 per cent of all UK operations for children with epilepsy
  • paediatric cancer services including bone marrow transplants – with University College London Hospitals (UCLH), they are one of the largest centres in Europe for children with cancer
  • nephrology and renal transplants
  • children treated from overseas in our International and Private Patient (IPP) wing

Through carrying out research with the Institute of Child Health, University of London and international partners, GOSH has developed a number of new clinical treatments and techniques that are used around the world.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page!

As many of you already know, my mum was diagnosed with terminal ovarian cancer in 2017. So far we've been lucky (yes, lucky) as we don't know how long she has left. This is only because of new forms of treatment and chemotherapy that have become available over the last few years. It's changed mum's diagnosis from 'terminal' to 'chronic'. Basically, as long as new treatments keep coming along, she can manage her cancer and live with it. 

I would love her to see my brother's wedding, my daughter's first Christmas, first steps, her first day of school. There's so much that my mum would miss out on without new treatments and support. I know there are millions of families in the same boat as us and I want to help out this Christmas season!

If you want to see what your donation could do, click this link https://www.cancerresearchuk.org/get-involved/do-your-own-fundraising/veg-pledge/the-difference-your-money-makes

Any pennies you could give would be just fantastic to help give hope to the people and their families who are struggling with cancer.

Love you all <3

story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

An elected ward councillor since May 2010 and a long-standing Charville resident, Cllr Fyfe served the community as a council 'street champion' by reporting concerns of residents and working to resolve them.

He listened to residents' ideas and suggestions during his popular ward surgeries, and lobbied for local improvements, including library refurbishments, road resurfacing and high street upgrades. He also served on the council's Planning Committee.

Cllr Fyfe was an active member of the Church of St Nicholas and was well known in the local community for his kindness. A keen allotment gardener, he regularly entered the council's Autumn Show with his wife Anna, displaying their award-winning homegrown fruit and vegetables.

Cllr Neil Fyfe

story:
Thank you for visiting our Just Giving Page.

Tighnabruaich Lifeboat Station has a  B class, Atlantic 85 lifeboat, B-862 James & Helen Mason  and the volunteer crew are available 24/7 for anyone who needs their help and are always be there to answer that call.

RNLI lifeboats in Scotland protect hundreds of communities with a 24-hour search and rescue service. Our volunteer crews rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from.

Scotlands unrivalled coasts and waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike, with millions travelling to enjoy them, and work on them each year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all 46 of the lifeboat stations in Scotland is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the pounds start to add up. It costs an average of £155k to run a lifeboat station in Scotland but this year, with the implications of Covid-19, we havent been able to fundraise to help keep our lifeboats afloat.

We rely on donations from the public to continue saving lives at sea and on inland water

All funds raised are restricted to Lifeboat Stations in Scotland.

By taking part in The Big Winter Wander, you and your friends and family can reconnect with our country's beautiful wildlife and help protect it. The funds you raise will help us campaign to protect wildlife here, and around the world. Nature has been there to offer us comfort during difficult times, and now its our time to give back.
